thread.title: Tigers' Malapit relaxed going into state finals
thread.title_full: Tigers' Malapit relaxed going into state finals

title: Tigers' Malapit relaxed going into state finals
text:
Activate your digital access. Tigers' Malapit relaxed going into state finals Yorktown's Reece Malapit shares her mindset going into the girls golf state finals this weekend. Video by Ryan O'Gara Ryan O'Gara , rogara@muncie.gannett.com 5:54 p.m. EDT October 1, 2015 Buy Photo Reece Malapit with Yorktown takes a chip shot on Saturday during the girls golf sectional at Crestview Golf Club. (Photo: Corey Ohlenkamp/The Star Press) Buy Photo 1 CONNECT 8 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
YORKTOWN — Just before she left for her practice round Thursday morning, Reece Malapit conceded she was a little bit nervous for the girls golf state finals this weekend. 
Then she backtracked. 
“I guess I shouldn’t be that nervous because there’s not a lot of expectations on me to win,” the Yorktown junior said, “so I can go out there and play my hardest.” 
And that’s been in stark contrast to just about every round she has played this season. 
As Malapit tees off at 9:15 a.m. Friday in the first of two rounds at Prairie View Golf Club in Carmel, she won’t have the weight of the expectations that come along with being the lead golfer for Yorktown. After Morgan Clark and Rachel Johnson graduated, Malapit put a lot of pressure on herself to be the one to make it to state. 
Now that she qualified after shooting a 75 at the Lapel Regional last week, she can just play. But she did say the pressure was kind of a good thing. 
“In the first few matches (this season), I was pretty nervous because a lot of people were relying on me to play well,” Malapit said. “But that kind of made me play better, because I had so many supporters behind me. There were a lot of people following me in the paper, and they’d come up to me and say, ‘Good job yesterday,’ or whatever. That just kind of motivated me.” 
That’s worked for her. Malapit has just one nine-hole score in the 40s this season and no 18-hole scores in the 80s, trimming five strokes off her average from her sophomore season. She shot 74 to win the Central Sectional two weeks ago. That 91 she shot at the New Castle Regional last season seems like a long time ago. Buy Photo 
Reece Malapit with Yorktown tees off the next hole on Saturday during the girls golf sectional at Crestview Golf Club. (Photo: Corey Ohlenkamp/The Star Press, Corey Ohlenkamp/The Star Press) 
As a freshman, Malapit was Yorktown’s No. 3 golfer and shot 82 and 80 as the Tigers finished fifth as a team. This year she’s the only ECI qualifier, and she’s on a course that she’s played several times before but hasn’t been able to score the way she wants. 
That’s why Malapit is going to try to slow her rounds down this game, at least mentally, after she kind of got away from it last weekend. 
“I’m just going to play hole by hole and shot by shot,” Malapit said. “I think at regionals, I looked at more of a total score. Like when I said a ‘bad 75’ in the newspaper the other day, I really did mean it, just because my mental game was off. That’s key for tournaments as big as state. You need to go hole by hole and shot by shot and go from there.” 
Contact sports features writer Ryan O’Gara at (765) 213-5829. Follow him on Twitter @RyanOGaraTSP . 1 CONNECT 8 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://tspne.ws/1KOU04f TOP VIDEOS
